brief_summary.textblock:
Carbohydrates are an integral component of sports nutrition. Providing carbohydrate (CHO)
      during exercise delays the onset of fatigue and improves exercise performance by maintaining
      high rates of CHO oxidation. Traditionally, glucose, or glucose polymers have been the
      preferential CHO source found in sports drinks. However, during the intestinal absorption of
      large amounts of glucose (>1.2 g/min), sodium-dependent glucose transporters (SGLT1) may
      become fully saturated, potentially limiting the rate of exogenous CHO oxidation. In an
      effort to evade this limitation, research has suggested using multiple transportable
      carbohydrates in the composition of sports drinks. Multiple transportable carbohydrates are
      combinations  of  simple  sugars  that  use  different  intestinal  transporters  during
      the absorption process. Ingesting multiple transportable carbohydrates may enhance the
      capacity for total intestinal CHO absorption, leading to an increase in the rate of
      exogenous CHO oxidation. Our purpose will be to examine the disaccharide sucrose in it's
      ability to provide exogenous fuel during and following prolonged exercise.

clinical_study.brief_title: Carbohydrate Use During and Following Exercise
clinical_study.condition: Carbohydrate Oxidation and Glycogen Utilization During and Following Exercise

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Healthy

          -  Male

          -  18 - 40 years of age

          -  Endurance trained cyclist/triathlete

          -  VO2 max ≥ 50 ml/kg/min

          -  BMI < 25 kg/m2

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Use of medication

          -  Smoking

intervention.description: Various types of carbohydrate ingested during and following exercise

clinical_study.official_title: Sucrose as a Preferred Carbohydrate in Sports Nutrition

oversight_info.authority: Netherlands: The Central Committee on Research Involving Human Subjects (CCMO)
